In the very end of March, for example, or beginning of April, we had, this year, instead of the old-established “borrowing-days,”The last three days of March, reputedly noted for bad weather. some three or four of the most blazing and really oppressively hot days; which again soon gave place to bitter grey or rainy north-east winds, very unfavourable for all things and persons; and when at last the real summer came, and we had (ever since the beginning of May) the beautifullest clear genial days and nights, and on Wednesday last I had put on my final summer-clothes (white hat, and black cobwebs of I know not what name), behold! there comes another change, colder and colder, and today I am wrapt in my thick winter-dressinggown again, and Jane down stairs has been obliged to kindle a brisk fire in spite of her scoured grate! But the wind today, in spite of its cold, is all out of the South, and I still prophesy we are to have rain; which will be well worth suffering on other accounts.

Poor old Mr Buller,Charles Buller, Sr.—I know not if I ever told you how weak and unwell he had grown: an attack of apoplexy above a year ago almost quite ruined him: and now it is all over; he died the day before yesterday, at a place called Richmond where they had taken a house, some 7 miles [west]Word omitted. of this. It will be a sad loss to poor Mrs Buller, who is herself too one of the weakliest creatures I ever saw living: I think she will not long survive him; for he was the chief care she had.—— Another death that we are interested by is that of poor Lord Ashburton, concerning whom you might perhaps notice a rascally article in the Times, one day. It is the same Lord Ashburton at whose big mansion, “the Grange,” you have sometimes known me: Alverstoke, where his son and son’s wife sometimes entertained us, was another house of his. His death was somewhat sudden; a kind of ague caught a[t his]Letter and word omitted. daughter’s house where he was on a visit,Alexander Baring, 1st Baron Ashburton, died 13 May, at Longleat, the seat of his da., the marchioness of Bath, in Wiltshire, after a few days’ illness. The long obituary in the Times, 15 May, speaks of him as “the only man created a peer whose principal pursuit in life was commerce” and as “a man with very slender talents for oratory or legislation.” Though critical, the account recalls his part in making the Ashburton-Webster treaty with the United States, 1842 (see 14:42TC to TSS, 13 Feb. 1842), and says that in private life he was reported to be “pre-eminently amiable.” since that warm weather began: he is to be buried this day,—and his big hospitable house, near which he is to lie, will now know him no more. What is remarkable enough, his two brothers, one elder and another younger, had already
died within a month;Sir Thomas Baring, bart., the oldest brother, d. 3 April; Henry Baring (1776–1848), the youngest brother, d. 13 April. and now the three old men, after many wanderings over the world, have all concluded their pilgrimage, and as it were lain down to rest together.— The now Lord Ashburton (Mr Baring, our friend) is, as his father was, a very worthy man; and I hope will do good in his day and generation, as at least he has a real desire to do: he is now immensely rich; but, having no children, and for himself no silly vanity, I believe does not in the least rejoice at such a lot: poor fellow, he looked miserably ill the day I called on him after his return from the sad scene, and, tho’ we did not speak of that, I found him miserably thin and pale, and the picture of a sorrow which well became him. One could not but ask oneself again, thinking of 60 thousand a year: “Alas, what is the use of it?”Cf. 5:268TC to WG, 1 May 1831. Perhaps about this hour he is laying his father’s head in the grave.

As for us, we have not suffered much from the bad weather; Jane, while the sun continued shining, had even got quite strong (for her), tho’ now she is a little shrunk in again. I have been writing some other “Articles,” as you would see in the Examiner and Spectator:“Legislation for Ireland,” Examiner, 13 May; “Ireland and the British Chief Governor” and “Irish Regiments (of the New Æra),” Spectator, 13 May. by the bye, will you send these on to Alick, if you still have them at hand? Also if the Article on Louis Philippe (a good while back) is anywhere in your possession, would Jenny clip it accurately out, mark the date of it on the margin, and send it me. Jane had a copy here, but has by mistake parted with it, and now there is none to be had readily. If you have it not, however, then don’t in the least mind.— I have a good many “Articles” still lying in me; and indeed I have been thinking of late seriously, whether I should not set up some little bit Paper of my own, and publish them there.Emerson wrote to his wife, 8 June: “Carlyle talks of editing a newspaper he has so much to say about the evil times” (Rusk 4:81). Espinasse says that when the ed. of the Spectator could tolerate no more than two of TC’s articles, “Carlyle was now convinced that he could not find in British journalism as then constituted a pulpit from which to preach to the governing classes. He began to talk of starting an organ of his own, which … he spoke of as ‘Twopenny Trash’” (173). Thomas Erskine wrote to TC, 1 June: “I have read your articles, with the wish that you had some steady organ, through which you might converse with the people of these countries periodically.” But that is a little precarious, would certainly be very fashious [troublesome], and I do not like it much. On the other hand, there is no Newspaper that can stand my Articles; no single Newspaper that they would not blow the bottom out of in a short while! For example, the Examiner should have had all these three last Articles put together as one: but then poor little Lord John Russell is a pet of theirs, and I could not put them on doing such a thing; so had to cut the
Article in three, and publish two pieces of it in a declared enemy of his. This is too troublesome.— At worst, if nothing else will do, I can write the things in a Book; and really that is perhaps the best way, in other respects too, after all. We are going to have sore times in this country, I perceive; and the trade of a “Governor” will not long be possible as poor Lord John and the like of him are used to manage it. Our streets even here, what I never saw before, are getting encumbered with Irish beggars; and in the manufacturing districts, as I hear from people on the spot, there hardly ever was greater misery. Something does imperatively require to be done; and I want Lord John to know that,—and go about his business as soon as he can!

Jack is well here, and very busy; doing really a good work in a faithful manner; which will really be, and is already, a strength and comfort to him. He was here last night; we mostly see him somewhere every day.— Mrs Paulet, Miss Jewsbury, Mr Paulet, and a great rabble more have just returned upon us from Paris, where they have been for a fortnight, “larking” (as it is here called) that is, “out upon the ploy [out for a frolic].”Geraldine Jewsbury, the Paulets, and W. E. Forster left for Paris, 1 May, to see what they could of revolutionary activities there. In Paris they met Milnes, Emerson, and Arthur Hugh Clough (1819–61; ODNB see 20:76>TC to AHC, 17 Dec. 1845); they went shopping, attended the theater, visited Louis Blanc’s tailor workshop, etc. They returned, 16 May. Jewsbury met her Egyptian friend Charles Lambert in Paris, where both caught sight of the once-admired St. Simonian leader Barthélemy Prosper Enfantin (1796–1864; see 6:27TC to JAC, 21 Oct. 1831), as Varnhagen noted on Bölte’s information (MS: Varnhagen Collection, Jagiellonian Univ.). They saw the big Riot last monday; and seemed to find it, as all Paris was finding it, comical rather than tragical. I believe, all that affair will grow tragical enough before long!On 15 May the socialists, alarmed at the overwhelming majority of republicans in the recently elected national constituent assembly, which took over the powers of the provisional govt., rose in rebellion. They were suppressed by the National Guard, and the angered republicans voted to abolish the national workshops. For Forster’s description of their visit and the uprising, see Reid, Life of W. E. Forster 1:228–44.— But you see, dear Mother, I am again at the bottom of my paper. I must commend myself to Jenny, to Jean, James, and all the rest; and end. Adieu, dear Mother; bid some of them write soon. Ever your affectionate
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JS[JST], 21 May. MS: NLS 581.566. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN STEILL

docBody.p:
Dear Sir,—Could you furnish me with half-a-dozen Copies of that Paper on
the influx of Irish into Scotland;Scotland for the Scotch—at least with one Copy, for I have lent mine away, and cannot get it back.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord C[LC], 26 May. MS: Clarendon Papers, Bodleian Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD CLARENDON

docBody.p: I know not whether I do a prudent or even a not impertinent act in offering for your perusal the inclosed Letter, unexpectedly received by me from a man who, to his own sorrow and that of all the world, has become of some importance in your sphere at present.

John Mitchell of the United Irishman called on me once at Chelsea, in the time of Smith O’Brien’s foolish “coalhole” business;John Mitchel (1815–75; ODNB see 20:105TC to GCD, 19 Jan. 1846, and 21:25–26JWC to TC, 23 Aug. 1846), Irish nationalist and journalist; see K. J. Fielding, “Ireland, John Mitchel, and his ‘sarcastic friend’ Thomas Carlyle,” Literatur im Kontext—Literature in Context, Festschrift für Horst W. Drescher, ed. J. Schwend et al. (Frankfurt, 1992) 131–42. Mitchel and Gavan Duffy had been friends working together on the Nation. But as Mitchel grew increasingly militant in his advocacy of Irish national independence and the use of force, he broke with Duffy and set up The United Irishman, a Dublin weekly, 12 Feb. to 27 May. In it he attacked Lord Clarendon and incited rebellion. On 20 March he was charged with sedition but not prosecuted because of the govt.’s fear that it could not secure a jury conviction. Mitchel was charged under the new treason felony act, 13 May; tried, 25–26 May; sentenced, 27 May, to transportation for fourteen years; and dispatched to Spike Island (1 mi. S of Queenstown in Cork harbor) before being taken overseas. William Smith O’Brien (1803–64; ODNB), Irish nationalist, leader of Young Ireland, and M.P. for Limerick, 1835–49, had been taken into custody by the sergeant-at-arms, April–May 1846, for refusing to serve on a parliamentary railway committee. Mitchel met TC, 14 May 1846, on a delegation to visit Smith O’Brien. and, the autumn before last, I spent two days a good deal in his company at Dublin; from which opportunities of direct survey and communication, tho’ except by public rumour he has been a stranger to me since, I gathered the lasting conviction,—and perhaps have mentioned it even to yourself (once at Alverstoke, on a snowy walk,Probably in Feb. 1847; see 21:153TC to JAC, 4 Feb. 1847. in other circumstances than these),—that Mitchell, enveloped in such frightful aberrations, is nevertheless intrinsically a gifted, brave, and even noble minded young man; whom indeed it has now grown absolutely indispensable to silence; but who, had it not been for a certain windy “Liberator” and loud False-Prophet the baleful misleader of many,Daniel O’Connell. might have done his Country real service, and been a help, not a hindrance, to a noble minded Governor of Ireland. This
unexpected Letter, indicating to the same effect, and almost the only Letter I have ever had from poor Mitchell, has agitated various emotions in me; and I decide on offering it, as an additional and not quite worthless Document in the intricate Suit now pending. The Lord Lieutenant of Ireland stands a long way removed from the United Irishman divided from him by a most confused untransparent and bewildering medium. That the Lord Lieutenant should get to see him, on any side, for what he actually is,—this cannot tend to harm, but must tend to benefit only.

Nobody has seen the Letter but your friends Lord and Lady Ashburton, and accidentally Richard Milnes; all of whom are touched with sympathy for the misguided Mitchell. In the event of his being found guilty by a Jury, it is a natural desire that such a man, whatever doom is appointed him, may not be confounded with common Felons; and indeed I think there will arise a feeling that it might beseem the Lord Lieutenant’s magnanimity to subdue this man by nobleness and clemency rather than by force and rigour, should such a course seem possible;—to which effect, in the desired event of a condemnation, perhaps some Petition of a more formal character may arise among us here.Whatever effect TC’s letter had, Clarendon told Lord Grey, 29 May, that he had arranged (even before the trial) for “decent accommodation” for Mitchel on Spike Island and given orders “not to be too rigorous about cropping or clothing” (MS: Clarendon Papers).

For the present if, by way of answer, your Lordship will, without word spoken or written,Lord Clarendon replied to TC, 30 May: “I thank you for sending me Mitchells letter wh is to me a document of peculiar interest & importance for it proves what I have too often heard asserted but never before had sufficient ground for believing, viz that Mitchell is not quite sane or that his brain is occasionally excited by opium or other potent stimulants. No one can read these two powerfully written sheets of dreamy aberrations without feeling that Mitchell is a fanatic, but he is fanatic all the more dangerous for being as you truly say a gifted, brave & even a nobleminded man. My enquiries led me to believe that such was his character & I felt respect for him. I even admired the outspoken courage … altho I was the principal mark for his invective, & tho’ he called upon me to prosecute him … [and] altho I was censured on all sides for not putting the law in force, I determined not to interfere with Mitchell until I became convinced that he was really doing harm.” But when Mitchell was widely listened to and aimed not only “to establish a republic in Ireland of wh. he was to be the head, but also a regular Jacquerie, & to kill every possessor of property in order to secure that tabula rasa …, why then I felt that there was no longer an option, … that the Govt shd put him down or he the Govt. must be tried. / Even now it is inexpressibly painful to me to have had even indirectly a part in banishing Mitchell … & if he had furnished the slightest pretext for the exercise of mercy I wd have been the first to press it upon the favorable consideration of the Govt., but that was not in his character to do, & you will have seen that even after sentence was passed upon him he reaffirmed all the principles & opinions for wh he had been convicted—he must be a hero or a martyr, & if he cannot make himself President of the Irish Republic he will not move a finger to save himself from transportation.” please to stamp a bit of hot wax on that Letter and let
the Post-Office do the rest, I shall take it as a kind forgiveness of this intrusion, and as all the answer that is either fit or desirable in the actual circumstances.TC also wrote to Mitchel about the same time, noting in his Journal, 12 July: “Irish Mitchel, (poor fellow) he is now in Bermuda, as a felon. Letter from him, letter to him, to and from Ld Clarendon: was really sorry for poor Mitchel; but what help?” Years later, 12 Sept. 1866, Mitchel was to write from Paris: “It is time for me to acknowledge receipt or your letter dated May 1848—Not that it calls for an answer, seeing that it is itself an answer to a letter from me. That letter was handed to me just as they were carrying me into Court to receive (what they called) sentence, & to be thence carried off beyond sea. Could not read it then—saw it was from you, and sent it to my wife to be kept for me—knowing that if it were found with me it wd be taken away by my enemy. So it was three years old when I got it to read” (MS: NLS 1768.171). Thomas Erskine wrote to TC, 1 June: “What do you think of this curious heroico-pathetic scene at the conviction of John Mitchel for madness I should say, still more than for felony.”

closer.salute: I have the honour to be / Your Lordship’s / Most obedt obliged

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: His Excy
The Earl of Clarendon &c &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-JPE, 29 May. MS: Yale. Pbd: W. A. Speck, “New Letters of Carlyle to Eckermann,” Yale Review 15 (July 1926):752–53. John Peter Eckermann (1792–1854), Goethe’s friend and literary asst., author of Conversations with Goethe; see TC to G, 25 Sept. 1828.
div3.head: TC TO J. P. ECKERMANN

docBody.p: Having a sure opportunity today, I write you a small word which I have long been anxious to send, had I known distinctly whither to address it. My understanding still is that Weimar is your headquarters; but a notion, gathered probably from Mr Marshall,James Marshall, sec. to the grand duke of Weimar. possesses me that you are sometimes absent for considerable periods from Weimar: so on the whole, this little Note, concerning the Faust Ms. entrusted to me last year,See 21:244TC to CKJB, 29 June 1847. is not written till now.

Mr Marshall, I doubt not, informed you of my endeavours in regard to that; and how, at last, as the likeliest thing feasible, I had put it into the hands of the Ritter Bunsen,In England he was usually known as Chevalier Bunsen. Ritter means “knight.” the Prussian Ambassador here, who cheerfully undertook to offer it to the King of Prussia, and advise his acceptance of it and his making you a present equal to £50 in return. You yourself, I remember, stated some Bedenklichkeiten [doubtfulness] as to Humboldt
at the Prussian Court;F. H. Alexander von Humboldt (1769–1859), Prussian naturalist and diplomat. Amalie Bölte wrote to Varnhagen, 14 Dec. 1847, that she had recently told TC about the letters of Humboldt’s brother Wilhelm (1767–1835), Briefe an eine Freundin (Leipzig, 1847), which Varnhagen would send him. She indicated to TC “that Humboldt put duty as the first purpose in life, and I asked him if he didn’t think Humboldt’s attitude was too harsh. He gave me a long angry glare … and burst out: ‘You ask me that question which has been the curse of my life which haunts me by day and by night. If you will not drive me mad, do not repeat it’” (Böltes Briefe 49, trans.). She appears to test TC’s views against those of Varnhagen, who also found the work “too monkish, too ascetic” (Varnhagen, Briefe an eine Freundin 54). which also were duly submitted by me to Bunsen: but, in spite of these (which seemed to him very easy to guard against), he decided to persevere; and did persevere, and do as he had promised, it would appear, before or shortly after Mr Marshall’s departure from England. This was the fact I should have communicated to you long ago,—but have, in my idle uncertainties, neglected till now. It is still all the fact I have on the subject. Some four or five months ago I inquired of Bn whether he had heard any news of the matter? To which he answered, None whatever. The Ms., and the advice what to do with it, had been sent to his Prussian Majesty, and as no answer in contradiction had come, he, Ritter Bunsen, had no doubt, the Ms. was now lying in the Royal Library at Berlin, and the expected return in your hands at Weimar.— So stands it on my side: since that I have heard nothing.
Pray have the kindness to write me directly whether Bunsen’s theory of the business is the correct fact! I hope it is; but if not, it ought not to rest there.

I long for your Third Volume of Gespräche which already sends a good rumour of itself into these far regions.The third vol. of Eckermann’s Gespräche mit Goethe … 1823–32 (Leipzig, 1848); see 9:61TC to JAC, 12 Sept. 1836. TC’s letter was possibly prompted by one from W. Weissenborn, who wrote, 23 May, from Weimar, asking permission to send him “a relic of Schiller’s,” a model of the table on which he wrote, covered with part of the original oilcloth. If TC agreed, he would send it “with the 3d Vol. of the Conversations of Göthe, which has just been published and which Dr. Eckermann is anxious to let you have as soon as possible.” Will you give our kind regards, our sincere hopes and wishes, to Mr Marshall; who has left a very lively remembrance of himself in this house.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[EC?], 2 June. MS: Sold at Anderson Auction Gallery, New York City, 17 May 1915. 3¼ pp. The sale notice identifies the addressee only as “a publisher.” Chapman is the most likely because TC wrote John Forster, [6 July], about a MS by David Masson “which Chapman lately had in hand.“
div3.head: TC TO [EDWARD CHAPMAN?]

docBody.p:
[Introducing “Mr. Masson, an excellent, ingenuous and ingenious man
used to hard, silent labour, … already well skilled in literary composition.“]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JE, 5 June. Addr: Trinity College / Cambridge. MS: Trinity. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH EDLESTON,

docBody.p: After some delay, I have had that matter of the Dudley-Wyatt Letter and Mr Hartshorne looked into at the Museum, by a sure hand; and, last night, got final report upon it.Edleston wrote, 11 May, sending further information about Cromwell’s letter on behalf of Dudley Wyatt. Charles Henry Hartshorne (1802–65; ODNB), antiquary, pbd. The Book of Rarities in the University of Cambridge: illustrated by original letters and notes, biographical, literary, and antiquarian (1829), in which he printed the letter about Dudley Wyatt from the copy in the Harleian MSS in the British Museum. The “sure hand” was probably John Bruce or possibly Thomas Watts.

The reference to “Harl. Mss. 7053,” it wd seem, leads to nothing whatever; merely indicates the place (Book, Chapter and verse) whence Hartshorne took (or rather might have taken) his Note, which he has printed accurately, without adding a word of his own, either at the beginning or the end. That is all. The “N.B.” too belongs to Harl. Mss. No 7053,—which is a Volume consisting of “detached excerpts chiefly or wholly from the Baker Mss.,” copied at what date I did not ascertain.TC takes note of this information in Works 6:295 and indicates: “The Harl. MSS copy adds: ‘N.B. Upon this Letter Sir Dudley Wyatt was readmitted,’—but did not stay, as would appear.”

closer.salute: Believe me / Dear Sir / Yours very truly /

div3.sourceNote: TC-DT, 7 June. MS: Trinity. Hitherto unpbd. Dawson Turner (1775–1858; ODNB see TC to EF, 10 Dec. 1844), botanist and antiquary of Gt. Yarmouth.
div3.head: TC TO DAWSON TURNER

docBody.p: I have read, with much attention, the Four Letters of Oliver Cromwell, lately published by you in the Norwich A[r]chaeological &c;See TC to JF, 18 March. Letter omitted. and must beg, for my own special objects, to have the liberty of addressing one question to you: Whether, in a word, the Letters are autograph or not?

I suppose them to be all autograph; but you do not anywhere expressly say so, that I can find; and, at p. 43, you casually speak as if the Authenticity of the Letters were or could be confirmed by internal evidence,—as if the external evidence were not of itself quite beyond question. Oliver’s handwriting, I need not tell you, is well known for its peculiarities still visible in many specimens, and could be sworn to in any Court of Justice. Pray have the kindness to satisfy me in one word as to this: in another edition of the Cromwell Book (when we come to that), I of course mean to introduce these Letters, and ought to say whether they are autograph or not, as now in your hands.They were autograph letters, printed and so indicated in Works 6:153–56, 166–67, 171–74; 9:221–24.

If autograph, as I suppose, the Letter pp. 51–55 is especially curious; for it has been printed, in the Old Newspapers, and in Rushworth (V.278), these two centuries:—printed, as you may see too, in that Book of mine (I.182), all except the first paragraph (p. 51 of yours) and a bit of the last (pp. 53–4), which have been omitted for very obvious reasons.See Works 6:153–56, where TC also notes the omissions in newspaper sources and in John Rushworth, Historical Collections, 7 vols. (1659–1701) (see Works 6:60). This was the only one of Turner’s letters that TC had previously printed. I suppose therefore it may be the oldest Newspaper Letter now in existence!— Tho’ of course it was not from it, but from a copy furnished, and slightly doctored, by the official persons, that the Newspapers got their material.— — “Captain Margerie” I find named again, still Captain of Horse, in 1651, “troop of 120 men”; but know nothing more whatever of him.See Works 6:166–67. TC was never able to identify Ralph Margery, capt. in Cromwell’s own regt. in 1644 and in Sir Robert Pye’s in the New Model: “Of Captain Margery, elsewhere than in that Suffolk Troop now mustering, I know nothing” (6:166).

closer.salute: Believe me / Dear Sir / Yours very truly /

ps.p: Dawson Turner Esq

div3.sourceNote: TC-CWR, 8 June. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:22–23. Charles Weatherby Reynell (1798–1892), printer, of Reynell and Weight, Little Pulteney St., St. James, Westminster, printers of the Examiner (see also TC to JSM, 9 Jan. 1837).
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES W. REYNELL

docBody.p: The bearer of this is Mr. Espinasse, a friend of mine, and known also to Mr. Forster,John Forster, ed. of the Examiner since 1 Nov. 1847.—who, I am very sure, had he been with you, would have warmly seconded the errand that now brings Mr. Espinasse.

He comes, namely, with a paragraph about Mr. Emerson’s Lectures, for
next Examiner; and I much wish you would put him in communication with the proper party for that object.No mention of Emerson’s lectures appears in the next Examiner, 10 June; but on 17 June a letter appeared, dated Hampstead, 14 June: “Sir,—The lectures of Mr. Ralph Waldo Emerson leave only one thing to be regretted, viz., that they cannot be heard by the whole literary and artistic public of the metropolis. The guinea for the course renders this impossible. How many there are who love beauty, and know well what it is, and create it afresh every day, for their fellow men; and yet they cannot reap guineas for their own instruction. I would therefore suggest to Mr Emerson, through your influential trumpet (what I dare not suggest as a private friend), that he present the literary men of London with his utterances on a liberal scale. It might be done by fixing some small admission charge. … I feel that it ought to be done, because Emerson is a phenomenon whose like is not in the world, and to miss him is to lose an important, informing fact, out of the nineteenth century. … [signed] AN ATTENDANT ON EMERSON’S PRESENT COURSE.” In Mr. Forster’s absence, I think I can safely recommend this, as right for every one; and certainly I do myself much desire it.Espinasse reports that TC’s attitudes toward Emerson’s lectures was at best ambivalent. “Very soon after the delivery of the first lecture I accompanied Carlyle to Emerson’s domicile, a visit apparently intended to be one of congratulation on his lecturing success. Emerson was at home, and Carlyle seemed to find the process of congratulation rather embarrassing. He could get out little more than that the lecture was ‘very Emersonian,’ which, considering that Emerson had been the lecturer, was not striking or enthusiastic praise. Then the subject was swiftly dismissed and succeeded by a conversation on a common friend. … Elsewhere than in Emerson’s presence, ‘Moonshine’ pithily expressed Carlyle’s opinion on his London lectures. But, before Emerson left England for home a few weeks afterwards, Carlyle spoke more kindly of his friend’s lectures as ‘intellectual sonatas,’ and of the friend himself as ‘a beautiful figure among those talking Yankees,’ and the ideal of an American gentleman” (163–64).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JT, 9 June. MS: Strouse. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:9–10, who identifies the correspondent as Julia Tosswill (b. 1827), nicknamed May; m., 1851, a Hodgson.
div3.head: TC TO JULIA TOSSWILL

docBody.p:
You have sent me a beautiful Book-marker, and a beautiful expression of your youthful regard; both of which I accept with thanks.In an unpbd. essay, “Some Old Letters,” Julia Hodgson wrote that in 1848 she sent a letter to TC because she had been “devouring everything of Carlyle’s that I could obtain, and at last I could no longer refrain from letting him know my gratitude for the new world of thought, which he had opened out to me.” She had made a bookmarker with the motto “Ernst ist das Leben“ (from the prol. to Schiller’s Wallenstein, a favorite quotation of TC’s and the motto to Past and Present) and sent it to TC, “pleading that as he had taught me Hero-worship, he would excuse my enthusiasm.” When she received TC’s response, she wrote, “Words can hardly describe my delight” (Wilson, Carlyle 5:9). Yours is the
season of admiration, and generous young gratitude,—wise and lasting, or transient and unwise. Much of it will die away in you as you grow older; but much also, I hope, will continue. For the quantity of wise admiration that remains with us, measures accurately our wealth in this world.

Be happy in your pleasant leafy Reigate,—which I once rode thro’, on a summer morning, such as this may be, seven years ago,To visit J. C. Hare at Lewes, Sussex, in early Aug. 1840; see 12:222TC to JAC, 10 Aug. 1840. Reigate is in Surrey, 21 mi. S of London. and shall remember now with new interest for your little innocent sake:—read my poor Books till you have learned all I had to say to you, and continue to love me a little so long as you can.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HD, 9 June. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Henry Drummond (1786–1860; ODNB see TC to JWC, 17 Aug. 1831), banker, politician, and a founder of the Catholic Apostolic Church, in which he was an apostle and prophet, lived in Albury, Surrey, 3 mi. E of Guildford.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY DRUMMOND

docBody.p: After some delay, your obliging Note,—with an apology from some Namesake of mine in the Hyde-Park region,T. Carlisle, 6 Hyde Pk. Pl., W Oxford St.—arrives at what I believe to be its true destination. Thanks for your continued goodwill to me, for your kind wishes and proposals.

Certainly I should like well to see Albury, which must be a doubly pleasant place in this bright leafy season: but, alas, there is no such thinskinned miserable traveller as I am; shattered to pieces by any tumult, or length of locomotion; unable to sleep in foreign beds &c &c; and the thought strikes me that it is chiefly, after all, the living Master of Albury that it wd do me good to see, and to exchange thoughts with, in these sad bodeful times! Which latter benefit, I always think, (even tho’ I can eat no dinners) might be attainable some time in London itself. Add to all which that I am quite unusually out of sorts at present, and engaged in moreover three times a week to attend Emerson’s Lectures,Espinasse says: “When I spoke of the high ethical ideal which Emerson held up to us, Carlyle replied that Emerson’s ethics consisted chiefly of ‘prohibitions.’” Further, TC said: “Mrs. Carlyle was more dissatisfied than her husband with Emerson’s ethics. Dilating in his high-flown optimistic way on the ultimate triumph of good over evil, the lecturer went the length of saying that even when in a certain haunt of sensual vice, unmentionable to ears polite (though Emerson called it by its plain English name [a brothel]), man is still tending upwards, or words to that effect. Mrs. Carlyle’s moral indignation at this statement knew no bounds, and for some time she could scarcely speak of Emerson with patience. I now and then fancied that after Emerson had been banqueted and welcomed by so many great and distinguished people in London, she viewed him, with a certain wife-like jealousy, as a sort of rival of her husband. Emerson’s admiration for her abated visibly, till at last he was heard to say that the society of ‘the lady’ … was worth cultivating, mainly because she was the person who could tell you most about the husband” (Espinasse 162–63). Emerson, on the other hand, believed, as he wrote to his wife, 16 June, that “Carlyle takes a lively interest in our lectures … & he is a very observed auditor tis very plain.” Many famous people come and “a great many more curiosities, but none better than Jane Carlyle & Mrs Bancroft who honestly come” (Rusk 4:84).—to one of which (there will remain just one after your return) you also ought to go.

closer.salute: Believe [me]Word omitted. always, / Yours with much regard /

div3.sourceNote: TC-CLB, 10 June. MS: Offered for sale in Maggs catalogue, Jan. 1946, item 394. Cecilia Lucy Brightwell (1811–75; ODNB), etcher and author.
div3.head: TC TO CECILIA LUCY BRIGHTWELL

docBody.p: I accept with many thanks your two Drawings of Oliver’s old House in Ely; which it surely was a happy inspiration that induced you to make; and which I, for my share, am very happy indeed to possess. The physiognomy of that old mansion is very recognisable to me; I miss nothing, except the old broken Horse block in front of the House, from which Oliver, among others, no doubt, had often mounted in ancient days: it was broken in two when I saw it,On 6 Sept. 1842; see 15:74–75TC to MAC, 7 Sept. 1842, and 82TC to JAC, 9 Sept. 1842. but the pieces were still too big for quite convenient removal, tho’ now, I suppose, the new Innkeeper has had them tumbled away.

Many thanks for what you have done; and if on future journeyings you come on any other surviving traces of O. C.’s habitation and warfare in this world, and will please to take an authentic portrait of them or of any of them, be sure you are deserving well, not of me but of all persons, and are turning your art to the most indubitable account. …

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LA], [11 June]. MS: Marquess of Northampton. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by Emerson’s third lecture, 10 June, in the series of six “On the Mind and Manners of the Nineteenth Century” at the Literary and Scientific Inst., 17 Edwards St., Portman Sq., 6–17 June. Lady Harriet was now Lady Ashburton. Emerson reports her presence in his audience (Rusk 4:84).
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Mr C. must make you the Report of Lecture 3d;“Tendencies and Duties of Men of Thought,” in which Emerson says TC took “a lively interest.” Further, “Carlyle too makes loud Scottish Covenanter gruntings of laudation, or, at least, of consideration, when any thing strikes him, to the edifying of the attentive vicinity” (Rusk 4:84, 85). for this one “tacked on” to The Sublime rather than to The Ridiculous, and my memory (more shame to me!) is retentive of only the Ridiculous in human speech. He (my Husband) likened the former Lecture to the Tune of ‘Over the Water to Charlie,’The second lecture, 8 June, was “Relation of Intellect to Natural Science.” The tune is a setting of the Jacobite lyric; both are given in James Hogg’s Jacobite Relics of Scotland, second ser. (Edinburgh, 1821). as he had once heard it played on an indifferent fiddle; the last was more in the style of ‘With one consent let all the Earth’ played on a (barrel-)organ;A hymn based on Ps. 100, usually sung to the “Old Hundredth” tune. or of that mystical Fantasia on the violincello with which Albert in the last chapter of Consuelo thrills the two Artist-souls who had come from remote lands and up a steep mountain to ask him for ‘The Solution.’Not in Sand’s Consuelo (1843) but its sequel, La Comtesse de Rudolstadt (1844), ch. 41, the last chapter, which begins with the magical sound of “the harmonica, that recently invented instrument.” The audience were quite charmed; so beautiful it all sounded, so profound, and lofty, and prophetic! but ask any one of them, or the man himself, what that tongue-sonate ‘wished of you,’ and the answer could only be; “Dont know the least in the world; further than, that you should “prick the slumberous side of the Giant who dwells in the unseen—the Angel who stood by God in the day of Creation—and stimulate Him (the Giant—the Angel) into all-searching, all-pervading activity,” said Giant or Angel having been precised as “The Instinct within us—that first Look of the Soul into every object.” By all which, if he meant to say in plain English, that it would be well we should give more heed to our instincts, I, for one, whatever the fish or flower may do, most cordially “think along with him.” On the whole we shall none of us be wiser for the Lecture I fear, but they amuse, and can do no possible harm— “a song of triumph“—over no victory—voila tout [that is all]!

The new-charmed Duchess has not come again—has found, it would
seem, something more unintelligible for her elsewhere.Probably Harriet Elizabeth Georgiana (1806–68; ODNB), duchess of Sutherland, though Emerson reported her present only at subsequent lectures (Rusk 4:84, 85); he was to dine with her, 26 June (Rusk 4:86). Lady Byron sat in her place, pale and transparent as a wax candleAnne Isabella, b. Milbanke (1792–1860), Lady Byron, the poet’s widow. She had attended Emerson’s lecture of 8 June, when Bancroft introduced them (Rusk 4:81); they were to meet her again at Anna Jameson’s (Rusk 4:86). Ah!— I recollected how I once walked half an hour, to and fro, in the rain, before an Edinr Book-shop; to catch sacred glimpses of—that woman’s skirts! and I sighed, that “the rude hand of Time” should have so effectually “swept the down” (as a Lady once said to me) “from the cheek of my beautiful enthusiasm.”Coterie speech; see 5:388TC to JWC, 31 Aug. 1831.

Miss Wynn told us in returning from the Lecture that Lord Sligo in his capacity of Special Constable had “seized two cart-loads of arms“—probably some old brace of pistols—and that the Rising was looked for today instead of tomorrow—but I hear only church-bells, no TocsinIn England, where thousands of special constables were resworn, 10 June, and strong forces of police suppressed and dispersed numerous Chartist meetings planned for Whit Monday, 12 June. The meetings were in sympathy with unrest in Ireland after Mitchel’s trial, where a new Irish League was forming uniting the Confederation and the old O’Connellite Repeal Assoc. George John Browne (1820–96), 3d marquess of Sligo.— She told us too, what you have perhaps heard, that a gentleman (?) went up to Milnes in the House of Commons, and said he understood that he (Milnes) now sent his washing to Mrs Cuffy;Referring to William Cuffey (Cuffay), prominent Chartist, member of the Convention (April 1848), one of several armed Chartists to be arrested, 16 Aug., tried for inciting rebellion and fire-raising, 26 Sept., and sentenced to life transportation; see Examiner, 30 Sept. and 7 Oct. Mrs. Cuffey was mentioned in the evidence. Milnes’s sympathy for the new French revolution was allied to the fact that he had also been “all for the Charter,” both positions mocked by his fellow M.P.s (Pope-Hennessy, Monckton Milnes, the Years of Promise 1809–1815, 281). Emerson thought Milnes “a little careless & sloven in his dress” (Journals and Miscellaneous Notebooks 10:530). but that there was so little of it, and what was, so thoroughly soiled, that poor Mrs Cuffy was frantic. And Milnes had “taken this joke very much to heart.” If I were Milnes, I would call out a few of these Jokers and shoot one, at least, dead—for the example’s sake.

Mrs Philips, Mrs Buller’s niece, was here this morning and told me that Lady Lewis was going to Richmond tomorrow to try to dissuade Mrs Buller from her scheme of “building a small house in Kensal Green“—“something in the form of a Temple over Mr Bullers grave—which they may retire to when they like—”Catherine Aurora ("Kitty") Phillips, b. Kirkpatrick (1802–89), Isabella Buller’s paternal cousin; see 3:166TC to JCE, 4 Oct. 1824. Clementina, b. Kirkpatrick, Lady Louis, Isabella Buller’s elder sister; see 2:5TC to JCE, 12 Jan. 1822, and 5:164–65TC to JAC, 18 Sept. 1830. Kensal Green Cemetery, in London; see 9:104TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836. Amalie Bölte wrote to Varnhagen, 14 Dec. 1847, sending him JWC’s letter to her of 23 Dec. 1843 (see 17:208–12JWC to AB, 23 Dec. 1843) and “a small note of Mrs Phillips, Carlyle’s first love, if one can call it a love. She is … daughter of an Indian princess, has a coffee brown complexion, and auburn hair. He didn’t know anything about the skin of a woman in those days. She is very friendly, gentle and good. Certainly that would have suited him well, it would have calmed him down. … She has now married a handsome but dim-witted man.” She was still “greatly interested” in TC and talked to Bölte for hours about him, “whereby I learn many a thing about his past life and being which would otherwise have remained secret to me. He never mentioned love to her. I also doubt whether he ever felt anything like that.” She would have liked to help him, but “it is the eternal curse of women that they cannot do anything independently” (Böltes Briefe 51, trans.). Dear! dear! She must not be suffered to do that!

Emerson is dining here today and a Welshman whom Mr C once staid three weeks with,Charles Redwood, whom TC visited in Wales, July 1843; see 16:235–81TC to JWC, 6 July 1843. and my Brother in law—and they are now looking for tea I suppose—the dinner went off charmingly—well-cooked and well-waited—and what is of more enduring interest to my household good my maidAnne Brown. “Household good“: Paradise Lost 9:233. has persuaded me that her two ‘accidents’ really were accidental, and stays under the condition that I am to regulate her intercourse with her Lover according to my own ideas of propriety.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LA], [12 June?]. MS: Marquess of Northampton. Hitherto unpbd. In spite of JWC’s addressing her as Lady Harriet, when she had become Lady Ashburton upon the death of her father-in-law, 13 May, this letter is almost certainly to be dated the same week as JWC to Lady A[LA], [14 June], since both apparently refer to the search for a servant for the dowager Lady Ashburton.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Since your note arrived at breakfast; I have enquired out, seen, and taken the particulars of two possible scullery-maids, and as it is now only twelve of the clock I may come on the traces of some more of them in the course of the day.

No 1 is a large, strapping young woman, with a physiognomy that hovers betwixt sense and softness—“will be three and twenty next September“—has lived three years with a family in Upper Cheyne Row—single servant there—not liable to colds—can have a good character from her present mistress who “has known her from a child“—“is not afraid of work“—“is leaving, of her own accord, for the heaviness of the work(?)—has in fact already left officially, another servant being come in her place; but her mistress “let her stay, doing needle-work till she find a place to suit her—” has no objection to live in the country all the year round or for any
number of years round—“rather prefers the country“—had 12£ of wages where she is—would prefer the situation of scullery maid “in a high family” to any other situation being “desirous to get on into cook“—is not, I think, without promptings of ambition. Finally No 1 is, Irish and thinks no shame of herself for that.

No 2 is less in stature—considerably—upper half of her face cheery and intelligent—under half questionable; a mouthful of teeth slightly projecting to one side give it something of a shilly-shallying look— She is two and twenty—is single servant at No 10 of this street—went there in room of a Sister who fell sick, and her sister having died, had stayed on ten months without having intended it—is leaving now of her own accord having “strong inclinations for cooking” and her present mistress doing all the cooking herself—would like of all things the place of scullery-maid “in a good Family,” where she could “learn something“—has had eight pounds a year of wages where she is; but would “expect a bit more if she went into a good family“—“can have a satisfactory character from her present Mistress and can assure me that she is very respectably connected“—no objections to the country, “Oh no indeed!"—"rather likes heat” (this taste was elicited by my question; if she were strong enough for hot kitchen-work?) No 2 has every drop of blood in her English

Both these Damsels will seek no further, till I have heard whether you would like either or both of them sent to Bath House for further investigation. If I hear of any other more promising I will write again.

I enclose a letter from India which contains some rather interesting details of English Life at Loodiana. The Writer is a beautiful little deaf Lady who bestowed herself and fortune on that Capt Mackenzie who was, after Lady Sale, our greatest Afghanistan Lion.Helen Mackenzie m. to Colin Mackenzie (1806–81; ODNB), army officer in India; see 18:11JWC to JW, 13 April 1844. In her letter of 15 March she said that she wrote “with the hope of hearing of you both & recalling ourselves to your kindly recollections, & not because I have anything very interesting to communicate,” although she went on to give a critical and descriptive account of her and her husband’s life in Ludhiana, E Punjab. She pbd. the journals of her stay as Life in the Mission, the Camp, and the Zenana; or Six Years in India, 3 vols. (1853). Florentia, Lady Sale, b. Wynch (1790?–1853; ODNB), widow of Sir Robert Henry Sale (1782–1845), army officer in India, shared the horrors of the British retreat from Kabul, 1842, was taken captive, and held till rescued; she pbd. her Journal of the Disasters in Affghanistan (1843). I never saw such an instance of a woman loving a man “for the dangers he had passed”Othello 1.3. She wrote that in India “you are thrown entirely upon each other for society & I am sure that is very good for it knits even the most united Husbands & wives still closer.”— The moment Capt M. began his Tale, which he had to tell over at least once in every company; the little deaf wife, however occupied elsewhere, seemed to know by instinct, and would hasten towards him, and sit down with her
ear within two inches of his mouth, and exhibit all the different phases of emotion which his narrative could possibly have excited in her at the first hearing—and all this without the least affectation in the world I really believe—she always struck me as a most sincere, natural little woman. I send too a note of female criticism on the Halfsisters which Lady Ashburton may perhaps like to read, as one small evidence that all my friends who think and write upon woman are not so entirely immoral after all! it is from a sister of Mrs Paulets, Emma Newton, who wrote a book in one volume called the Unbeliever.Emma Newton, whom JWC had described as an “emancipated Evangelical” (see 19:131–32JWC to TC, 5 Aug. 1845), author of The Modern Unbeliever (1847). The whole subject was sensitive and, about this time, drove TC to writing on George Sandism and eroticism; see Fred Kaplan, “‘Phallus-Worship’” (1848): Unpublished Manuscripts III—A Response to the Revolution of 1848,” Carlyle Newsletter 2 (1980):19–23. “The new Sand religion,” TC wrote, “is not yet developed into articles; creeds, and bodies of divinity; far from that. Much lies yet undeveloped … and huge world-wide mythologies, little suspected of being mythic, struggle to unfold themselves. … The Bible of Phallus-worship is the Circulating-library” (Kaplan 22, 23). The MS is at Yale.

div3.sourceNote: TC-PR, 13 June. MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO PATRICK ROBERTSON

docBody.p:
Thanks for the Packet you have sent me, which is very welcome in more ways than one;—acceptable not only as a mark of your remembrance, but also as the first notice I get of a salutary, just, and most important decision of a social question in which all good Scotchmen take interest. I go wholly with you,—so far as I have legs to go on such a matter,—in your reading of those old Acts, and application of them to present wants; and I cannot but sincerely wish and hope your judgement may be affirmed decisively by the Inner House,The first and second divisions of the court of session in Edinburgh, which mainly heard appeals from the outer house (where Lord Robertson sat) or from sheriff courts. and become valid among us, and recognised universally as the Law of the Land.Apparently referring to a judgment by Lord Robertson, pbd. 10 June, on the case of an able-bodied man refused relief for his children by the parish. Robertson upheld the sheriff’s decision that the children could not work or find subsistence and were therefore entitled to relief. He had probably sent TC his pbd. notes on the case, which insisted that “the law of no Christian country can enact such a barbarous system of tardy and perhaps useless relief, as that the party must become sick from actual want before is offered that which, timeously administered, would save him from sickness altogether.” The Scotsman, 14 June, pbd. this judgment with an appeal to the inner house on a similar case. The appeal court judges, including Francis, Lord Jeffrey (1773–1850; ODNB see 1:223TC to AC, 26 Jan. 1820 and later vols.), also dismissed a parish’s attempt to refuse relief, so showing that any further appeal against Robertson’s judgment would be refused, as TC hoped. It will save the passing of a new Act, with perhaps
much agitation and confusion attendant thereon, if it do: for indisputably enough, that is the Law of the Universe (in some small measure,—that, till we get more!)—and if it be not the Law of Scotland, it is pity!— — I shall be anxious to hear what the Inner House resolves upon; and if, when the time comes, you happen to have any waste Newspaper or other as convenient monitor beside you, and can goodnaturedly remember me and my desires so far, I shall be thankful for such tidings,—which otherwise might linger on their way hither.

We were sorry not to see you again; but hope it will not be long till you revisit these regions, perhaps with more leisure on your hands. My wife,—mindful of the “Hydrastisy,”Apparently a shower bath; cf. 16:260TC to JWC, 11 July 1843. The reference is unexplained. and other sublime considerations out of old times,—will be very sorry to be absent a second time when you call.

closer.salute: Believe me / Dear Lord Robertson / Sincerely Yours

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LA], [14 June]. MS: Marquess of Northampton. Quot: Hansons, NE. 365 Dated by the fact that of Emerson’s six lectures (6–17 June), only two were on a Tues., 6 and 13 June, and by JWC’s statement that “Nothing was brought home from yesterday’s lecture,” implying that she had heard at least one lecture already. June 14 was Wed.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Not so fast! dear Lady! I saw yesterday two other young women, the last of whom looked to me the best of the whole lot, but as I have only her looks to go by as yet; I must take time to seek up her details. She came quite incidentally to offer herself to me, sent by my Brother-in-law’s Landlady, who knew of my late casualties.Apparently referring to Anne Brown and her “accidents”; see JWC to Lady ALA, [11 June]. She was to marry in the autumn. For previous potential servants, see JWC to Lady ALA, [12? June]. I was just going to bed with a sick-headach at the moment, so I could not investigate her very minutely: but even thro the universal disgust of a sick-headach, she looked to me a fine, frank, intelligent affectionate creature (tho’ Mrs AtchisonThe Ashburtons’ housekeeper. probably does not insist on that last quality; it is a help rather than a hindrance in even a scullion) with the light compact make of a clever servant, and a little up-to-anything-air which quite won my esteem. I will go today and inquire into
her history a little—& if nothing comes out to belie her appearance, will send her to Lady A.The dowager Lady Ashburton. rather than any of the others.

Nothing brought home from yesterday’s lecture except a Persian Proverb—“For the Man who wears a shoe, it is all the same as if the whole earth were covered with leather.”“Poetry and Eloquence” was the subject, 13 June. Emerson worked the quotation into a later lecture, “Wealth,” in the series “The Conduct of Life” delivered in the early 1850s. See The Complete Works of Ralph Waldo Emerson, ed. E. W. Emerson (Boston and New York, 1904) 6:95. And this startling assertion of Emerson’s own; “Men now-a-days are born with knives in their heads!”— no wonder one has such headaches!

What little attention I was able to bestow on anything yesterday got spell-bound by the Duchess of S.’s gown!Of Sutherland’s. As my Helen exclaimed over a Virgin & Child in the National Gallery “My! Oh My! how expensive!”Helen Mitchell’s phrase, now coterie speech; see 15:86JWC to JW, 12 Sept. 1842. and the leading idea of it so incomprehensible! White lace “wandering at its own sweet will”Wordsworth, “Composed upon Westminster Bridge,” 12. all a-down a figured grey silk—and interspersed with the oddest looking little plantations of grey and white ribbon—her beautiful arms were bare up to the elbows, for the thin white lace which covered them so far was mere delusion—and her cloak and her bonnet who shall dare to describe? She was escorted yesterday by Lyall the Geologist who looked, my Husband said, “very much embarrassed poor fellow”!Charles Lyell. and sat where she could be seen in detail—in the enclosed space for the Lecturer!— I shall be delighted to go to you with C on Friday— Meanwhile I will go while it is fair and take perquisitions of the little Sarah GreenPresumably the prospective servant.
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-SL, 14 June. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO SAMUEL LAURENCE

docBody.p: Will you request Mr Lynch (whose address I have mislaid) to send me Two Copies of that illustrious Print (of myself by the Sun and you),—or, in brief, forward to him the enclosed Note, after completing the address on it; and that will be the briefer method!Presumably James Henry Lynch (d. 1868), engraver and lithographer; he exhibited portraits at the Royal Academy, 1856–65. This is probably a print from a Laurence drawing based on a photograph ("by the Sun and you") and probably the one reprod. by Wilson, Carlyle 4:opp. 80; but cf. Froude, Carlyle 3:frontispiece. Emerson wrote to his wife, 21 June: “A new print has been taken of his [TC’s] head & he has rolled up one to send to you” (Rusk 4:86).
We hope and believe you are very busy; but must see you again before long. Meanwhile, “Bear a hand, and well speed you!” that is the word.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AC, 16 June. MS: MUL. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:59–61 inc.; Marrs 663–66.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p: Before your American mail leaves today I will write you a few words, lest none other of them happen to write. I am very busy, and rather out of sorts for writing; but you will take my poor contribution as the best I have. Some weeks ago, after a good deal of delay, there arrived a short Letter, which you had written hastily at Brantford; very welcome to us, as indicating at least that you were all well; and only a few days after there came another (addressed to our Mother, I think), considerably later in date:—it would seem there is some small place in Canada itself called “London,” and in two instances now your Letters hither have gone to that poor London,In Ontario, ca. 45 mi. ESE of Brantford. and taken the air there a week or two before they came on! Pray put “England,” therefore, or “By Steamer,” upon your Letter;—and for the rest, especially in summer-time, the mails are so frequent now (one every fortnight, or even every week), you had better just write when you feel at leisure, any time, and put the sheet into the Post-Office to take its chance, if you have not by accident some clearer guidance. Jack also suggests that you should, once at least in every month, send our Mother a Newspaper: the address, in your hand, with two strokes (if kind Providence enable you to that) will signify the essential to her, and the thing costs only a penny here, and I suppose very little on your side either. Attend to this, if you can.— I will endeavour to ascertain better, some day, when the mails do leave your shores: but in the meanwhile, follow the above (viz. to write when you like), and we shall not be far wrong.

We had a Letter today from Scotsbrig, of Isabella’s writing: she reports very comfortably indeed of our good Mother, who went home from a long visit to Dumfries and Jenny, about a month ago; and is at present very tolerably well, according to Isabella,—“much better since she got into the country air again.” Doubtless the beautiful summer is a help to her; for
there was hardly ever finer weather,—warm winds and a fair proportion of soft rain;—the crops, they say, look beautiful, and are far ahead of the average for this season of the year in Annandale especially. This is all our news from that quarter. They do not write often; I write to my Mother without much reply. Jean has a new bairn lately (a girl, I think), which of course rather ties her hands in the writing way.Mary Aitken (1848–95), who m., 1879, TC’s nephew and future ed. Alexander Carlyle (1843–1931), Alexander’s son. Mary of the Gill has also a young child some months ago,—a boy, this time,James Austin.—as perhaps you have already heard. They are all well, or in their usual way, for anything we know or guess.

Not long since I had a Letter from Brother John, on his arriving at “Fredericksburgh near Simco,” which is a piece farther away from you than before.Their half-brother John Carlyle (1792?–1872; see 1:139TC to JCE, 2 Sept. 1818). Simcoe is a town in SE Ontario, 20 mi. SE of Brantford and ca. 8 mi. from Lake Erie. He wished to give me his new address for the Newspaper, which accordingly I have observed since then; he also lamented about some kind of argument or quarrel you and he had had, and how you said to him some thing about “selling his birth right for a mess of pottage,”Gen. 25:31–34.—which I wrote back to him was all nonsense; and a thing you probably meant very little by, and would have forgotten before you next met him. Poor fellow, do not be too severe on him!— Jack and I could not help laughing at the “mess of pottage,” when we figured to ourselves here how the thing had probably been. I have sent the Newspaper, and hope the poor fellow gets it duly—

We are in our usual poorish way of health here, which does not grow very brilliant in spite of the good weather: however, we still stir about in a grumbling way, and even Jane is pretty well on foot at present. Jack sticks obstinately to his task, and it proves very dreigh [slow] to get done: but I believe it will be really well done at last, and prove a useful thing.— I myself am beginning to write again,—for the wild revolutionary times urge me on;—but I do not get much under way yet; and indeed am much at a loss what form to throw the thing into: but I must bore along, “stogging and blonking [walking heavily and awkwardly]” (as you once defined Corson’sThe tenant at Craigenputtoch; see 12:247TC to AC, 10 Sept. 1840. ploughing); and nothing but persistence will find me out the right method. I once thought of writing a long set of articles for Newspapers, of which two samples I think were sent to you of late; but the thing does not well take that shape; and in fact I know not what to do with it, but shall gradually know.

I suppose you hear enough about our Chartists; and how the French, and indeed all Nations, are puddling deep in the quagmire of revolution and social distress: the Chartists do us next to no mischief here as yet (to us here at Chelsea, none at all); but the look of that concern is very ominous too, and I believe there are great miseries and confusions at no great distance for Britain generally, and bad days are coming, and must come before many years go! We cannot help it; I cannot:—nor do I see any hope of real remedy till long after our poor fight will have altogether ended, and that of our sons and grandsons perhaps too!— Much terrible distress prevails just now in the manufacturing regions; and the Irish people have got again into a large potatoe-crop this year, with which, if it fail, they will be in a bad way!— On the whole, I cannot but think you lucky, dear Brother, in spite of all your trials and sorrows, that you have got your family into a hopefuller land than this, and have a piece of soil of your own to till, and little else but Heaven to be responsible to. God keep you in his ways always, and so all will be well!—

A Captn Sterling here (John’s brother, the writer’s whom you know of) gave us a large map of Upper Canada, which he made while soldiering there. Here is the reduced copy of a scrap of it round Brantford; I want you to put down the exact situation of Bield, and send it back to me that we may know.— If there ever come anybody that could take a “Sketch” of the House &c— But that alas is not at all likely.

closer.salute: You will give our affectionate regards to Tom and Jane, and their Mother and all the rest. Let us hear soon that you continue busy and well; and describe to us as far as possible all you are occupied with. Farewell, dear Brother, for this time.

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LA], [16 June]. Quot: Hansons, NE 365. Dated by JWC’s promise to visit Lady Ashburton “with C on Friday”; see JWC to Lady A[LA], [14 June]. Fri. was 16 June.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I am making ready to accompany this afternoon; lest I don’t see you again at all.

div3.sourceNote: TC-SL, 19 June. MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO SAMUEL LAURENCE

docBody.p: Any friend of yours is welcome to me along with you, at any time.Laurence replied to TC’s note of 14 June on the same date, saying that he looked forward to calling on him soon and asking “may my friend Mr Geldart come too. I have some compunction in asking this, from a feeling that you would as leave not have strangers brought to you. But will you please say ‘once & all’ whether it is so or not. I will only add that he is not a stranger from the other side of the Atlantic.” Joseph Geldart (1810–82), Norfolk artist. I shd even like Geldert for his own sake, if he did not require such a frightful expenditure of breath for talking with him! But he is a good man; and cannot help being deafish. By all means bring him if he want to come— — Does Thornton Hunt never think of attending you on a charitable expedition hither?Thornton Leigh Hunt (1810–73; ODNB), journalist, Leigh Hunt’s oldest son; see 6:348TC to MAC, 16 March 1833. He is well liked here; his last appearance was decidedly successful, as we remember it.
Lynch has sent me the two Prints; no mortal knows of the existence of his Print here, or he might sell a good many;—but perhaps it is better so, for the thing is dreadfully ugly, after all!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 20 June. MS: RWEMA. Pbd: Norton, CE 2:195–96 inc.; Slater, CEC 440–41.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p:
We shall be very glad to become acquainted with Mrs Crowe, of whom already by report we know many favourable things.Catherine Crowe, b. Stevens (1800?–761790–1872; ODNB), novelist and writer on the supernatural; see 13:177JWC to JF, 10 July 1841. Emerson wrote to TC, 19 June: “Mrs. Crowe of Edinburgh, an excellent lady known to you & to many good people, wishes me to go to you with her. … I propose 1 o’clock on Thursday [22 June] for the invasion.” Emerson had met her in Edinburgh, where she had entertained him, in Feb. (Rusk 4:22, 23). Brown (of Portobello, Edinburgh) had given us intimation of her kind purposes towards Chelsea;Samuel Brown (1817–56; ODNB), chemist, atomic theorist, and writer; see 17:90TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1843 and E. S. Arbuckle, “Dr. Samuel Brown of Edinburgh,” Carlyle Annual 11 (1990):77–86. He was a devoted admirer of TC, who on the whole returned his high opinion. He wrote to TC, 15 June, that Catherine Crowe was leaving the next day for London for a fortnight: “She wishes particularly to see Mrs Carlyle and you. She is a kind of literary woman, … but it is not in that character she wishes to see you. It is simply as the friend of several of your friends; and, so far as you are concerned, as the reader of your works.” While Emerson was in Edinburgh he wrote enthusiastically about Brown as the most interesting person he had met (Rusk 4:23), and Brown exulted, “We ran into one like spheres of mercury” (Arbuckle 82). and now on Thursday you (please the PigsCoterie speech; see 9:376TC to MAC, 23 Dec. 1837.) shall see the adventure
achieved.— Two o’clock, not one, is the hour when labour ceases here,—if, alas, there be any “labour” so much as got begun; which latter is often enough the sad case. But at either hour we shall be ready for you.

I hope you penetrated the Armida Palace, and did your devoir to the sublime Duchess and her Luncheon yesterday!Armida’s palace, in Tasso’s Gerusalemme Liberata, was a synonym for magnificence. Emerson lunched with the Duchess of Sutherland at Stafford House, which, he thought, was “the best house in the kingdom, the Queen’s not excepted” (Rusk 4:89). I cannot without a certain internal amusement (foreign enough to my present humour) represent to myself such a conjunction of opposite stars! But you carry a new image off with you, and are a gainer, you. Allons [Forward].
My Papers here are in a state of distraction, state of despair! I see not what is to become of them and me.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: N.B. The Letter-Cover with a stamp worked into it, is already a stamped cover; and needs no new stamp, except the weight exceed half an ounce! How many additional pence, flung away in this manner, may you have given the Queen since you came among us!

My Wife arose without headache on Monday morning; but feels still a good deal beaten;—has not had “such a headache” for several years.Emerson wrote TC, 19 June: “It was sad to hear no good news last evening from Jane Carlyle.” He wrote to his wife, 21 June, that JWC “suffers like all good women of my acquaintance from cruel headachs, & on Sunday [18 June] was very ill. I learn she is better.” And he reported that TC “talks seriously about writing a newspaper or at least short offhand tracts to follow each other rapidly on the political questions of the day. … He is solitary, & impatient of people, he has no weakness of respect, poor man, such as is granted to other scholars I wot of, & I see no help for him. … He has I think some secret plan or counsel for the healing of the nation which he is maturing” (Rusk 4:86).

div3.sourceNote: TC-WS, 20 June. MS: Strathclyde Regional Archives. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM STIRLING

docBody.p:
You are very kind; and do not forget us, tho’ we see nothing of you. Certainly I will accept with thankfulness your Book on Spanish Art;Annals of the Artists of Spain, 3 vols. (1848). Stirling’s interest in Spain and Spanish art arose from his visits to Spain earlier in the decade. At the time Spanish art was a subject practically unexplored in Britain. and
endeavour to instruct myself a little in regard to those remote products of this opulent universe, and ascertain whether I have any heritage at all among them, under your guidance, which is understood to be the best. Many thanks to you beforehand.

Greenwich on Sunday would also be a most tempting proposal to any but a wretched Dyspeptic like myself,—who, alas, am obliged to decline all dinners, and to picture Heaven as a place where eating will be no longer needed! Not to say that I have a kind of regular engagement here at home (rendezvous with my Brother &c on that day of the week); and am at present, moreover, in quite unusually unfit condition for an adventure like yours.

This is the fact: and I the more regret it, as I also have a desire to know Mr Ford, whose Spanish Book I have decided to read some day (a great distinction in this particular house);Richard Ford (1796–1858; ODNB), critic and author of books on Spain. His Handbook for Travellers in Spain (1845; rev. edn., 1847) was a popular, learned guide. According to the ODNB, his obituary in the Times, attributed to Stirling, said of it that “so great a literary achievement had never before been performed under so humble a title.” and whose face and appearance, one day when I saw him with you, seemed decidedly promising. Cannot I meet such a man without an indigestion, then; wretch that I am? I will come any evening, and smoke a cigar with you and him, in Clarges StreetPresumably the Clarges St. Hotel. (he must be up to cigars); or if you will bring him down hither any evg he shall have our best welcome. That seems the best method.

On the whole, why don’t you come and see us oftener, you? We are not out one evening in twenty; but sit here quietly reading books,—perhaps idly listening to a little music (Coolun, Gilderoy,“Gilderoy” is a ballad; see 18:238TC to DL, 14 Oct. 1844. “Coolun” is an unidentified song. or such like) from the piano, now and then;—and in silence, as beseems the genus homo, “looking before and after”Cf. Shelley, “To a Skylark” st. 18. thro’ this huge whirlpool of an Existence,—not with too much profit, I fear! In fact, we are by no means busy in the evenings; and are glad to see the human face divine,Paradise Lost 3:44. when there seems to dwell any sense and friendliness behind it.— That is exactly the truth; and I would have you believe it,—and me
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-SB, 20 June. MS: NLS 7197.30. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO SAMUEL BROWN

docBody.p: We shall be happy to make acquaintance with Mrs Crowe, whenever she so pleases to honour us. The Lady is well known to us by report, and my Wife is specially cognisant of several of her Books:—a lady of whom many good testimonies from the Edinburgh quarter reach us here.JWC had liked Crowe’s Adventures of Susan Hopley (1841); see 13:177JWC to JF, 10 July 1841. Their mutual friends included the Jeffreys (probably both Francis and his brother John [1775–1848; see 13:11–12JWC to SS, 8 Jan. 1841]); John Hunter (1801–69; see 8:161JWC to SS, 30 June 1835), Edinburgh lawyer; Susan Stirling, b. Hunter (1799–1877; see 8:159–61JWC to SS, 30 June 1835, and 13:9JWC to SS, 8 Jan. 1841), JWC’s longtime friend; and Thomas Erskine.— Accordingly, it seems, the meeting is to take effect on Thursday first; and Emerson is to be the harbinger; a result which shall be very welcome. This matter, therefore, is settled.

I wish you had told me something about your own history past and prospective; which I never cease to take an interest in, tho’ it is somewhat dim and vague to me in these late times. Your old aim, I understand in general, continues still as a fixed polestar with you; which gives me assurance at least that the first condition of manful existence is not wanting to you.Brown’s aim was to prove the atomic composition of bodies. What can I say but, Persist, persist! Be open to new light, to hard lessons which we all need here; but be shut to new discouragements and foolish darknesses and dustclouds, which are lessons not from the Eternal Destinies but from the insignificant Temporary Accidents: the loyalest man is he that will best discriminate between the two; and on all of us it is incumbent to run with patience the race the race set before us!Thus in MS; Heb. 12:1.———

closer.salute: Believe me / Dear Sir / Yours very sincerely always

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LA], [28 June]. MS: Marquess of Northampton. Quot: Hansons, NE 364. Dated by Emerson’s lecture on “Domestic Life,” “delivered yesternight,” 27 June; see below.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
The James Lawrence that called at Bath House is the son of a Lawrence in Boston, who is one of the principal merchants in Massachusetts, perhaps the principal there or in Yankeeland generally, and is well and favourably known to all men on that side of the sea. James (whom
Emerson, I think, does not much know except generically) is understood to be his Father’s man in those extensive affairs.Emerson wrote to his wife, 28 June: “We have a good company of Americans here,” including James Lawrence, whom “I have not seen.” Rusk notes that a merchant named James Lawrence appears in The Boston Directory, 1848 (4:95). He was presumably the son of one of four brothers, all Boston merchants—William (1783–1848), Amos (1786–1852), Abbott (1792–1855), and Samuel, William’s partner. Perhaps his call was to the elder Lady Ashburton?Herself American; see 16:27TC to MAC, 20 Jan. 1843. Time’s tide lands us on new promontories, and ever new, and will not rest at all!— — The high child delivered yesternight his lecture on “Domestic Life,” not one of his best, to a large and highly unselect audience,—who missed the finer passages, but were fervently alive to whatever touched on progress of the species, the early closing movement, or such like.After his six lectures Emerson was persuaded to give three at Exeter Hall—23, 27, and 30 June—for the benefit of the Metropolitan Early Closing Assoc. He wrote to his wife, 16 June, “I must make amends for my aristocratic Lecturing in Edwards St at prices [five shillings a lecture] which exclude all my public, by reading three of my old chapters” (Rusk 4:83–84); and, 29 June, “Carlyle came on Tuesday Eve. [27 June;] & was seated by the joyful committee directly behind me, as I spoke, a thing odious to me” (Rusk 4:94). Lady Byron, alone of the Arixtoxy, was there. The air grew very hot;—the human heart at last began to get weary.— When Emerson ended, the Early Closing Movement itself (in the person of its Secretary,John Lilwall, gen. agent, 6 Horse Shoe Ct., Ludgate Hill. “Arixtoxy” thus in MS. a man with gloomy fat face, and no mouth properly, but only a kind of hole in his countenance) burst forth in a passionate manner; and discoursed, with a chaunting loud tone, for some time,—the audience leaking, alas, in streams, thro’ every orifice;—till at last they were mostly gone, and he ended and I got away—

Emerson is coming here tomorrow evg,Emerson wrote to his wife, 29 June: “Last night I was at Carlyle’s. They both, he & she are to come to Mr [John] Chapman’s tomorrow evening, to a sort of farewell party which Chapman invites my friends to” (Rusk 4:94). and Mrs Crowe with the eyes. You too have eyes—O heaven!—

closer.salute: God save the Queen,—my own Queen.

docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, [30 June]. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the review in the Examiner, 1 July, the day after this “Friday,” when TC sent it in hope of including it “this week,” and by the dinner at the Macreadys’, 28 June; see below.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
I myself know nothing of the famed M. Chopin;Frédéric Chopin (1810–49), Polish pianist and composer, was in Britain, 20 April–23 Nov., where he gave recitals in London and elsewhere. but here is a Criticism
upon some performance of his, and two very excellent friends of mineMary Rich and A. J. Scott, both friends of Jane Wilhelmina Stirling (see JWC to JSJWS, [10 July]), who was devoted to Chopin and encouraged and supported him during his visit. (much interested in Chopin, whom they consider a man of great modesty and moral worth as well as talent) are very anxious to see it in some Newspaper, next Sunday,—in the Examiner, of course, before all other Newpapers. I have undertaken to introduce it to you;—and for the rest, only that you will decide honestly, Yes or No, as your real judgement of the case is.The Examiner, 1 July (cont. 8 July), contains a highly laudatory review of Chopin’s matinée musicale, 23 June, at the home (99 Eaton Pl.) of Adelaide Sartoris, b. Kemble (1814?1815–79; ODNB), singer, author, and Chopin’s former pupil.
The Writer of it I am also (under seal of secrecy) permitted, on my suggestion, to name to you: The Revd A. Scott; a very superior man, and very well known to me this long while.

Do as you find good, therefore;—and faustum sit [good luck]. This is to go by special messenger, as I suppose there is no time to be lost at this hour of Friday,—alas, it is Friday! Is there any hope for us this week?
Come and see me soon. The MacreadyMacready noted, 28 June, that the Carlyles, among others, “dined with us” (Diaries 2:397). He was on strained terms with Forster. was all right—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-MAC, 7 [6] July. MS: NLS 521.69. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 3:439–40 inc. TC misdates, for he is writing on “thursday” and is to leave “tomorrow forenoon,” Fri., 7 July.
div3.head: TC TO MARGARET A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: It seems to me again too long since I have written to you; but the fault has not altogether been mine: besides, the only way to mend it is to write now, before any one get in to interrupt me; which accordingly I do, the first work of the day.

We are well in health, and glad to find from Isabella that at Scotsbrig too things go moderately well. This is all our news; but this, I think, is mainly what you want. We have had a good deal of rain lately, which doubtless was bad for the hay, but in other respects a favourable kind of weather,—very favourable to me for one, who like nothing so much as frequent showers in the London Summer. On the whole hitherto I hardly recollect a more pleasant season, so far as climate and temperature go, since we came here: a very grey summer indeed, cool to the skin, yet warm to the ground, for the wind has generally been at once genial and plentiful: and now, at last
within these three or four days, the Sun seems fairly to have got the upper hand, and we have real july weather, as bright blue and beautiful as heart could wish. Owing to the late rains, moreover, everything is unusually green, and as yet the wind keeps up amid the bright sunshine;—so that we do perfectly well in as far as weather concerns us. Jane still stirs about, pretty fresh for her; Jack is busy, drawing nigh the end of his task now;His trans. of the Inferno..—I, alas, am but beginning mine again, under many interruptions; and feel dreadfully “stiff to ye raise, Sandy, man!” Bundles of Papers are getting accumulated round me, but I think they will mostly need to be burnt at last, to make room for better.— Isabella tells us you are going to Moffat;Ca. 17 mi. NNE of Dumfries. which I much approve of: pray let her give us notice when you do go. It will suit very well indeed, if you can get good weather and a quiet lodging, both of which I hope are possible.

Doubtless you have been reading of these awful explosions in Paris, which interest everybody, and are indeed an alarming symptom of the misery of this poor time. To us the most interesting feature of all is this General Cavaignac who has had the command in that terrible business.
